full_conversation: Therapist: Welcome, Mrs. Amir. How are you feeling today?
Client: I'm feeling a bit anxious, to be honest. I've been dreading this session all week. The idea of revisiting that terrible airplane crash... it's just overwhelming.
Therapist: I understand. Your feelings are valid.
Client: Thank you. It's just... I've spent so long trying to forget it all. The thought of purposely bringing it up again terrifies me. What if I can't handle it? What if I completely fall apart?
Therapist: Those concerns are normal. We'll go at your pace.
Client: That's reassuring. But can you explain why we need to do this? I mean, isn't it better to just leave the past in the past?
Therapist: Facing memories can reduce their power over you.
Client: I see. So, by confronting these memories, I might actually feel less afraid of them in the long run? That makes sense, but it still sounds incredibly difficult.
Therapist: It is challenging, but you're not alone.
Client: I appreciate that. Can you tell me more about what exactly we'll be doing? What should I expect during this... exposure, did you call it?
Therapist: We'll revisit the memory gradually. You'll describe it aloud.
Client: Describe it aloud? Oh my... That sounds intense. Will I have to go into every detail? I'm worried about getting too emotional or not being able to continue.
Therapist: We'll start small. You can pause anytime.
Client: Okay, that's somewhat comforting. I suppose knowing I can stop if it gets too much helps. How long will this process take? Is it just for today's session?
Therapist: It's a process over several sessions. We'll build gradually.
Client: I see. That actually makes me feel a bit better. Knowing we're not trying to tackle everything at once. But what if I start having nightmares again or my anxiety gets worse?
Therapist: That's normal initially. We'll address it together.
Client: Alright. I trust you, but I'm still scared. This crash... it's affected so much of my life. My anxiety, my relationships... even my work has suffered. Will this really help?
Therapist: Many find it very effective for PTSD symptoms.
Client: I hope so. I'm willing to try, even though it's frightening. My husband has been so supportive, but I know this affects him too. I want to get better, for both of us.
Therapist: Your courage is admirable. Shall we begin?
Client: I... I think so. Yes. Let's do this. But please, if you see me getting too distressed, can you help me calm down? I'm worried about losing control.
Therapist: Absolutely. We'll use grounding techniques if needed.
Client: Thank you. That helps. Okay, I'm as ready as I'll ever be. Where do we start? Do I just... start talking about the crash?
Therapist: Start with the moments just before boarding.

Client: Alright. Well, I remember standing in line at the gate. It was a busy day at the airport. I was traveling for work, a conference in Dubai. I remember feeling a bit nervous, as I always do before flying, but nothing out of the ordinary...
